05512.Extra Information: Albert Clement’s dissertation „O Jesu, du edle Gabe : Studien zum Verhältnis von Text und Musik in den Choralpartiten und den kanonischen Veränderungen von Johann Sebastian Bach“ (Utrecht 1989) [“O Jesu, precious offering: Studies on the relation between lyrics and music in the Chorale Partitas and Canonic Variations by Johann Sebastian Bach”] makes a convincing point that the partita’s 10 variations are likely linked to the 10 stanzas of the hymn „O Jesu, du edle Gabe“.

00353.Genre Categories: Sonatas; For piano; Scores featuring the piano; For 1 player
00353.Work Title: Piano Sonata in D-flat major/E-flat major
00353.Alternative. Title: Piano Sonata No.7, Piano Sonata No.8
1897 − Franz Schubert's Werke, Breitkopf & Härtel (1st version)  1829 − Vienna: Pennauer (Plate 436) (2nd version)
00353.Extra Information: For the 1st version of the sonata, the Neue Schubert-Ausgabe published an alternative version of the 1st movement (Fassung der ersten Satzes nach der ersten Niederschrift). The Finale is a fragment, as the last page of the autograph, probably containing 17 bars, is lost. Its contents may be reconstructed from the parallel passages in the exposition and (for the coda) the 2nd version of the sonata. It is possible that the Scherzo in D-flat major (D.593/2), also composed in 1817, was originally conceived as the 3rd movement of the Sonata. The 1st version is numbered as Piano Sonata No.7 in both Classical Archives and the Wiener Urtext Edition; it is unnumbered in the Breitkopf & Härtel edition. The 2nd version is numbered as Piano Sonata No.7 in the Breitkopf & Härtel edition, and as Piano Sonata No.8 in the Wiener Urtext Edition; it is unnumbered in Classical Archives.
00353.Movements/Sections:
1 sonata (2 versions):
1st version

Allegro moderato (D♭ major)
Andante molto (C♯ minor)
Allegretto (D♭ major - fragment)

2nd version

Allegro moderato (E♭ major)
Andante molto (G minor)
Menuetto. Allegretto — Trio (E♭ major)
Allegro moderato (E♭ major)
00353.Opus/Catalogue Number: D.568 (2nd version published as Op.posth.122); 1st version was formerly D.567

318757.Name Aliases: Bagatelle No. 25; Bagatelle in A Minor, WoO 59, "Für Elise"; Για την Ελίζα; Μπαγκατέλα αρ. 25 σε Λα ελάσσονα, WoO 59; Για τη Λίζα; Για την Ελίζ; Bagatela No. 25; Lettre à Elise; من أجل إليزا; من أجل إليزأ; A小调巴加泰勒; 献给爱丽丝; 致特蕾莎; I Elise
318757.Authorities: WorldCat; Wikipedia; VIAF: 186663871; LCCN: n81133634; BNF: 147860559
1867 - in Neue Briefe Beethovens (ed. Ludwig Nohl, pp.28-33)
318757.Dedication: Therese Malfatti von Rohrenbach zu Dezza (supposed)
318757.Extra Information: What Ludwig Nohl claims to be the basis of his first publication of the work has never been found. All we have of the piece are (1) two lines of sketches from 1808 and (2) sketches from 1810 with pencil revisions from 1822, probably, for inclusion into the set of 11 Bagatelles, Op.119. The work as we know it today is entirely based on Ludwig Nohl's first edition, which in turn is very similar to the 1810 version of the work. The manuscript upon which Nohl based his edition is inscribed "Für Elise am 27 April zur Erinnerung von L.v.Bthvn" (for which scholarship has generally agreed that 1810 is the year) and apparently given to him by a certain Babeth Bredl from the possessions of Therese von Malfatti.

Schulenberg (Volume 3, p.65 et seq.) also regards an early date as more likely, noting that there is no possibility here that in honorem means in memoriam here (and that the subtitle may derive from the copyists, e.g. Kellner, in any event. 54984.Genre Categories: Allegrettos; For piano; Scores featuring the piano; For 1 player
1990 – Wydanie Narodowe Dzieł Fryderyka Chopina, Polskie Wydawnictwo Muzyczne
54984.Copyright Information: The reconstruction by Jan Ekier (1913-2014) is under copyright worldwide, because it contains significant editorial intervention. Please do not post scans of this edition or use this as a source in your own reconstruction as these will be deleted!
54984.External Links: Narodowy Instytut Fryderyka ChopinaHistory of the AllegrettoAll Music Guide
54984.Extra Information: Chopin's authorship of this work has often been questioned. No autograph exists, and the first known edition from the 1840s ascribes it to Charles Mayer, who most probably added music of his own: Mazurka in F-sharp major. The published edition is 218 bars long, but Jan Ekier attempted to reconstruct the sections plausibly composed by Chopin in the National Edition of 1990 (revised 2006).

03319.Movements/Sections:
6 sections:
 Arioso: Adagio. Ist eine Schmeichelung der Freunde,
um denselben von seiner Reise abzuhalten.

 (Andante). Ist eine Vorstellung unterschiedlicher Casuum, 
die ihm in der Fremde könnten vorfallen.

 Adagiosissimo: Ist ein allgemeines Lamento der Freunde.
(Andante con moto) Allhier kommen die Freunde
(weil sie doch sehen, daß es anders nicht sein kann) und nehmen Abschied.

 Aria di Postiglione: Allegro poco.
 Fuga all' imitazione die Posta [della cornetta di postiglione].

289792.Extra Information: According to letters by the composer, I gather, written in 4 days in April 1838? - Schissel. The 1850 revision is musically quite significant (several repeats were added, the endings of Nos. 4 and 5 were changed, 20 bars were inserted and 8 removed in No. 2, and dynamics, tempo markings and other agogics are in places very different). I've thus put the two in separate subcategories, hope that's ok. Cheap Imitation 04:26, 9 February 2016 (EST)

494709.Extra Information: Title of first English edition: "The Well-Tempered Clavier, or Preludes and Fugues through all tones and semitones, relating to the major third, that is, Ut Re Mi, as well as those related to the minor third, that is, Re Mi Fa. Compiled and prepared for the benefit and practice of young musicians desirous of learning, as well as for the entertainment of those already versed in this particular study, by Johann Sebastian Bach, Anno 1722". The Hoffmeister publication probably predates the Simrock by about a decade.
494709.notice: This page is only for complete editions and multiple selections from Das wohltemperierte Klavier II. For most arrangements, see the separate pagesfor the individual preludes and fugues. For the first set of 24 preludes and fugues, see: Das wohltemperierte Klavier I, BWV 846-869.

03180.Name Aliases: Piano Sonata No. 21 in C Major, Op. 53; Waldstein (apocrifo); L'aurora (apocrifo); Opus 53: Sonate nr. 21 i C-dur; 华德斯坦; 華德斯坦; Pianosonate nr. 21 (Beethoven); Sonata para piano n.º 21 en do mayor, Op. 53; L'Aurore
03180.Dedication: Count Ferdinand Ernst Gabriel von Waldstein (1762-1823)
03180.Extra Information: In the holograph, the introduzione is simply "Adagio" and the Rondo is simply "Allegretto" (sin molto / moderato) ... This sonata used to have a long "Andante" section. Beethoven didn't like it, so it became a separate work ("Andante favori") WoO 57. The "Introduzione (Adagio molto {?})" is now the middle movement that introduces the third movement. Deathgleaner 18:41, 26 December 2008 (EST)

04399.Genre Categories: Pastorales; For organ; Scores featuring the organ; For 1 player; For piano 4 hands (arr); Scores featuring the piano (arr); Scores featuring the piano 4 hands (arr); For 2 players (arr); For piano (arr); For 1 player (arr)
1845? – Compositionen für die Orgel - Leipzig: Edition Peters
04399.Extra Information: First movement incomplete. The autograph is lost. Peter Williams (The Organ Music of J. S. Bach, from p.196) gives the following - "Complete in P 287 (J P Kellner, after 1727?); also, via CPE Bach (P290, P277?, Am.B59?), and [a] lost MS used in Peters I; first movement only [survives] in copies via Kittel(?)" (note: the Darmstadt digitized collection, of works by JS and CPE Bach, is possibly one of the above - P290, P277 or Am.B59?).  There are other works where Williams mentions the possibility that Griepenkerl may have used a now-lost source in preparing his edition. Similarly, whilst Wilhelm Rust was editing several volumes for the Bach-Gesellschaft Ausgabe, it is likely that he used sources now lost. However, other issues arise with traits of Rust's editing.

518119.Genre Categories: Studies; For piano; Scores featuring the piano; For 1 player
518119.Movements/Sections:
68 studies in 3 books (12 in Schuberth edition)
Book 1
Exercises for gaining strength and independence of each individual finger with quiet hand, and chord-studies.
Book 2
Preparatory studies for the major and minor scales.
Book 3
Scales in thirds and sixths. Arpeggios, or broken scales.
Book 4
Chromatic scales and exercises. Scales in contrary motion.
Book 5
Repeated thirds, fourths and sixths, with various fingerings.
Exercises in thirds (formed from scales) in parallel and contrary motion.
Exercises in fourths and Sixths.
Book 6
Major, minor and chromatic scales in double-thirds and -sixths.
Book 7
Scales in chords of the sixth with various fingerings.
Arpeggios, or broken scales in double-thirds and -sixths, and chords of the sixth.
Chromatic thirds, fourths and sixths.
Octave scales, major and minor.
Book 8
Broken octaves.
Arpeggiated, or broken octave scales.
Chord-studies.
Shakes in thirds, sixths, fourths and octaves
Book 9
Chords of the diminished seventh.
Exercises with quiet hand.
Arpeggios, or broken chords
Book 10
Broken chords with various fingerings throughout all major and minor scales.
Book 11
Arpeggios in thirds and in sixths with various fingerings.
Book 12
Octave-studies with various fingerings and chord-studies.
[Table of Contents from Schuberth edition, Plate 6259.]

08927.Genre Categories: Sonatas; For piano; Scores featuring the piano; For 1 player
08927.Work Title: Piano Sonata in D-flat major/E-flat major
08927.Alternative. Title: Piano Sonata No.7, Piano Sonata No.8
1897 − Franz Schubert's Werke, Breitkopf & Härtel (1st version)  1829 − Vienna: Pennauer (Plate 436) (2nd version)
08927.Extra Information: For the 1st version of the sonata, the Neue Schubert-Ausgabe published an alternative version of the 1st movement (Fassung der ersten Satzes nach der ersten Niederschrift). The Finale is a fragment, as the last page of the autograph, probably containing 17 bars, is lost. Its contents may be reconstructed from the parallel passages in the exposition and (for the coda) the 2nd version of the sonata. It is possible that the Scherzo in D-flat major (D.593/2), also composed in 1817, was originally conceived as the 3rd movement of the Sonata. The 1st version is numbered as Piano Sonata No.7 in both Classical Archives and the Wiener Urtext Edition; it is unnumbered in the Breitkopf & Härtel edition. The 2nd version is numbered as Piano Sonata No.7 in the Breitkopf & Härtel edition, and as Piano Sonata No.8 in the Wiener Urtext Edition; it is unnumbered in Classical Archives.
08927.Movements/Sections:
1 sonata (2 versions):
1st version

Allegro moderato (D♭ major)
Andante molto (C♯ minor)
Allegretto (D♭ major - fragment)

2nd version

Allegro moderato (E♭ major)
Andante molto (G minor)
Menuetto. Allegretto — Trio (E♭ major)
Allegro moderato (E♭ major)
08927.Opus/Catalogue Number: D.568 (2nd version published as Op.posth.122); 1st version was formerly D.567
